title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _December_ 23.--Went to church to Borthwick with the family, and heard awell-composed, well-delivered, sensible discourse from Mr. Wright,[103]the clergyman--a different sort of person, I wot, from my old half-mad,half-drunken, little hump-back acquaintance Clunie,[104] renowned forsinging "The Auld Man's Mear's dead," and from the circumstance of hisbeing once interrupted in his minstrelsy by the information that his ownhorse had died in the stable.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Went to church to Borthwick with the family, and heard a well-composed, well-delivered, sensible discourse from Mr. Wright, 2 the clergyman a different sort of person, I wot, from my old half-mad, half-drunken, little hump-back acquaintance Clunie, 3 renowned for singing " The Auld Man's Mear 's dead," and from the circumstance of his being once interrupted in his minstrelsy by the information that his own horse had died in the stable.

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: About seven years ago I was well acquainted with a worthy little fellow of a clergyman, a Mr. Clunie, who sang it charmingly  ; and, at my request, Mr. Clarke took it down from his singing.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: About seven 3'ears ago I was well acquainted with a worthy little fellow of a clergyman, a Mr. Clunie, who sang it charmingly ; and, at my request, Mr. Clarke took it down from his singing.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: after his attainder in 1715, he experienced the same generous anddisinterested fidelity ; and Macpherson of Clunie, though an outlaw, and compelled to live for nine years in caves and woods, wasin no want of money or any thing that could be contiibuted by hispeople, who, after his death, continued the same assistance to hiswidow and family.

snippet: It is the property of H. Trotter, Esq. ofMortonhall; Braid, properly so called, belongingto Charles Gordon, Esq. of Clunie.
